com.nexmo.messaging.sdk.messages

Class Message

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.nexmo.messaging.sdk.messages.Message
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    BinaryMessage, TextMessage, UnicodeMessage, USSDDisplayMessage, USSDPromptMessage, WapPushMessage

    public abstract class Message
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable
    Message.java

    Created on 5 January 2011, 17:34

    Represents the details of a message that is to be submitted via the http api.
    Not instanciated directly, but instead via one of the sub-classes that represent a particular message type
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Paul Cook
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static int MESSAGE_TYPE_BINARY
      Message ia a binary SMS message with a custom UDH and binary payload
      static int MESSAGE_TYPE_TEXT
      Message ia a regular TEXT SMS message
      static int MESSAGE_TYPE_UNICODE
      Message is a unicode message, for sending messages in non-latin script to a supported handset
      static int MESSAGE_TYPE_USSD_DISPLAY
      Message is a USSD 'display' message that displays on handset but does not require a response
      static int MESSAGE_TYPE_USSD_PROMPT
      Message is a USSD 'prompt' message that requires a response from the end user
      static int MESSAGE_TYPE_WAPPUSH
      Message is a wap-push message to send a browsable / downloadable url to the handset

      Constructors

      Instanciate a new message request.
      This constructor exposes the full range of possible parameters and is not for general use Instead, it is accessed via super() in the constructors of various sub-classes that expose a relevant sub-set of the available parameters

    • Constructor Detail

      • Message

        protected Message(int type,
       java.lang.String from,
       java.lang.String to,
       java.lang.String messageBody,
       byte[] binaryMessageBody,
       byte[] binaryMessageUdh,
       java.lang.String clientReference,
       boolean unicode,
       boolean statusReportRequired,
       java.lang.String wapPushUrl,
       java.lang.String wapPushTitle,
       int wapPushValidity,
       MessageClass messageClass,
       java.lang.Integer protocolId)
        Instanciate a new message request.
        This constructor exposes the full range of possible parameters and is not for general use Instead, it is accessed via super() in the constructors of various sub-classes that expose a relevant sub-set of the available parameters
        Parameters:
        type - the type of message will influence the makeup of the request we post to the Nexmo server, and also the action taken by the Nexmo server in response to this message
        from - the 'from' address that will be seen on the handset when this message arrives, typically either a valid short-code / long code that can be replied to, or a short text description of the application sending the message (Max 11 chars)
        to - the phone number of the handset that you wish to send the message to
        messageBody - The text of the message to be sent to the handset
        binaryMessageBody - The raw binary message data to be sent to a handset. This api, and the Nexmo messaging service will send this data 'as-is' (in conjunction with the binary UDH) and will not make any corrections. so you should ensure that it is a correctly constructed message
        binaryMessageUdh - Most binary content will require a UserDataHeader portion of the message containing commands to enable the handset to interpret the binary data (for example, a binary ringtone, a wap-push, OverTheAir configuration, etc). Additionally, if you are sending a long text message as multiple concatenated messages and are performing this operation manually rather than using the automated long messaging handling in the Nexmo messaging service, then you will need to construct and include here an appropriate UserDataHeader field that describes the segmentation/re-assembly fields required to sucessfully concatenate multiple short messages.
        clientReference - This is a user definable reference that will be stored in the Nexmo messaging records. It will be available in detailed reporting / analytics In order to help with reconcilliation of messages
        unicode - This flag is set to true if the message needs to be submitted as a unicode message. This would be for scenario's where the message contains text that does not fit within the Latin GSM alphabet. Examples would be messages to be sent in non-western scripts, such as Arabic, Kanji, Chinese, etc.
        statusReportRequired - If set to true, then a delivery notification will be requested for this message delivery attempt. Upon receiving notification of delivery or failure from the network, the Nexmo platform will submit a notification to the url configured in your Nexmo REST account that represents the outcome of this message.
        wapPushUrl - This is the url that will be submitted to the handset and will appear as a browsable message in the Inbox.
        wapPushTitle - This is the title that will be associated with the url being submitted to the handset
        wapPushValidity - This is the length of time (in seconds) that the message will be available for once delivered to the handset. Once this time has expired, the url will no longer be visible on the handset to be browsed (Subject to handset compatibility)
        messageClass - (Optional) The message class that is to be applied to this message.
        protocolId - The value of the GSM Protocol ID field to be submitted with this message. Ordinarily this should be left as the default value of 0

        public byte[] getBinaryMessageUdh()
        Returns:
        byte[] Most binary content will require a UserDataHeader portion of the message containing commands to enable the handset to interpret the binary data (for example, a binary ringtone, a wap-push, OverTheAir configuration, etc). Additionally, if you are sending a long text message as multiple concatenated messages and are performing this operation manually rather than using the automated long messaging handling in the Nexmo messaging service, then you will need to construct and include here an appropriate UserDataHeader field that describes the segmentation/re-assembly fields required to sucessfully concatenate multiple short messages.
